Author: mv#8810
Content: I have a question about atomic cross-chain swaps.  What happens if the block on which one leg of the transaction was logged, is later orphaned?  Does the "atomic" nature of the swap force the other leg, on a different blockchain, to also  become invalid?

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: @mv if there are disagreements there are refunds.

Author: dan.#2473
Content: afaik there were updates to wait for x confs depending on the coins

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: Thanks for all your answers I'm off to bed have fun üòÄ

Author: mv#8810
Content: The Komodo whitepaper points out that there is no point at which a logged transaction is immune to being orphaned.  So waiting for 100 confirmations before releasing deposits makes it likely, but not certain, that the transaction will not be orphaned

Author: dan.#2473
Content: ive been out of the loop for some time, but, in the case of assetchains being swapped, they're at 3-6 confs for each part of the swap protocol.  As that gives time for a few notarizations to occur

Author: dan.#2473
Content: james is typing he will answer

Author: dan.#2473
Content: lol

Author: mv#8810
Content: okay

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it is just a normal orphan, then . it will just go into the mempool and get confirmed in the next block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but if you are swapping with a 51% attacker who is reorging the chain just to double spend on you, then the orhpaned tx wont be valid anymore. so for large amounts, use more confirms. for assetchains it is set to 3 so usually there is a notarization to protect it

Author: mv#8810
Content: Yes, notarized chains are relatively protected.  For other chains, the Bobs accepting coins are dependent on the security of those chains, and  are only protected by the confirmations.  What mechanism returns orphaned atomic swap legs to the mempool?  Is that automatic by the underlying protocol, automatic within the Barterdex / Hyperdex protocol, or manual, because the swap failed and the swappers manually retry it?

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: the underlying protocol

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: automatically by bitcoin code

Author: mv#8810
Content: Okay.  I'm thinking of cases like the timewarp attacks on Verge last month... it orphaned many of the Verge blocks, and the newly mined blocks had no transactions in them.  I suppose once the attack ends, the accepted blocks have not removed the transaction from the mempool, so it would finally get processed and later confirmed.

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: Verge is not a good comparison...

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: We're talking about real tech here.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless you are swapping XVG

Content: touche

Author: mv#8810
Content: Heh... we are talking about atomic swaps, and what vulnerabilities remain when using atomic swaps with relatively insecure blockchains.
